Comments_List: Developed expertise within my specific research parameters, as well as more practice of how to conduct independent research. It's not a skill that develops overnight, and I'm glad I had a semester to get the hang of it.
I learned how to research independently and helped design a project.
Research, Identifying Invertebrates, Communication with faculty, experimental design, data analysis.
I learned how to independently manage elements of a research project, write grant proposals, and organize summer research.

Research for credit is entirely what you make of it; the structure is dependent on you and your PI. There is no guidance whatsoever, which allows for a lot of freedom. Don't forget the final paper -- there was no reminder of the paper's existence this year, so the turnaround was a bit quick.
More communication about when application for the course is due and when the final report is due.
The strengths and weaknesses of this course depend entirely on your mentor and their involvement in your project.

I'd definitely recommend taking research for credit if you've already established yourself in a lab and have a project in place, and if you're motivated enough to be the driving force behind your project in a course largely without structure.
It is a great way to learn a lot about something you are interested in but can't find a class in which it is featured.
Yes, if you're interested in doing independent research and are motivated and self-driven.
